Dear Mr. Kolodchin:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
(date). Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the Implementation Sustainability and Exit
Plan (ISEP) and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except the
following:
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
One of seven employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s annual tuberculosis screening due 3/31/18 was six
days late on 4/6/18.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2018.
R400. 4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(4) Training opportunities for direct care staff shall include, but
are not limited to all of the following:
(h) First aid.
One of seven employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s updated first aid/CPR certification was due by
5/30/18 and completed 8/23/18.
R400.4152 Initial documentation
At the time of admission, all the following shall be in the
resident’s case record:
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided as
required by in R400.4132.
Three of three open child records reviewed, and one of eight
closed records reviewed as an open record did not show clear
documentation that the grievance policy was provided to child’s
parent or the referral source.
1

R400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following shall be documented in the case record within 14
days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new location
of the child.
One of eight closed child records reviewed did not show a clear
explanation of the reason for the child’s discharge.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
Five of eight closed child records reviewed did not show an
assessment of the child’s needs that remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
Seven of eight closed child records reviewed did not show what
if any service would be provided directly by the agency after
discharge.
It is noted, the agency uses a discharge form, but it does not
consistently address each category in the same manner, and
the categories used as heading do not consistently address
aspects required by these rules. Nor did the agency utilized an
updated form it amended to address subrule(d).
R400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(2) For an unplanned discharge, an institution shall provide a
brief summary or other documentation of the circumstances
surrounding the discharge.
One of eight closed child records reviewed showed the child
was discharged again medical advice, but the discharge form
listed the child as stable. An explanation of what lead to the
unplanned discharge was not clearly explained.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training (3)
 The agency was apprised most of its staff training shall not be on-line.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.4116 Chief administrator; responsibilities (2)
 The facility’s chief administrator’s report was very limited and did not give a clear
indication it encompassed the agency’s internal review. The agency was advised
on this report. Some examples were requested by the agency, and they will be
solicited and provided.
R400.4166 Discharge plan (1)
The agency was advised revision of its discharge form to denote the categories
documented in the rule as headings, may aid it in demonstrating full compliance to
the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection where it
received four rule violations. Those rule violations related to personnel records. The
agency made gains in those areas. It received one repeat violation this Inspection.
The agency has another chief administrator. This person is not new to the agency.
He is the founder who assumed the chief administrator’s role following the departure
3

of the prior staff person. The facility reported its staff has primary been stable, but its
child placement census has fluctuated over the last year. The facility client numbers
have been extremely low over the last few months. Upon this consultant onsite on
2/1/19, the facility did not have a child in placement. To assess for rule compliance in
the area of open residents, a closed record, where the resident had remained in place
for fifteen days was also reviewed. The agency received placement of three
residents the prior week and another site visit occurred. The chief administrator
reported one reason for the lower census numbers could be related to referral
sources being under a fault impression that the facility does not take aggressive
children. He reported the agency has concerns with children who have a history of
aggression with their peer, but not necessarily with aggressive behaviors. The chief
administrator is working with referral sources/hospitals to clarify these issues.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue their regular license.
